<div class="markdown"><h4>Data Science Applications to Astronomy</h4><h1>Week 3: Model Building I</h1><h2>Probability</h2></div>





<div class="markdown"><h1>Terminology</h1><p>We'll use words that sound familiar, but have technical meanings distinct from their everyday usage.  E.g.,</p><ul><li><p>Model</p></li><li><p>Likelihood</p></li></ul></div>


<div class="markdown"><h1>Model</h1><h2>Scientific Model vs Statistical Model</h2><ul><li><p>What are the differences?</p></li></ul><h2>Scientific Model</h2><ul><li><p>Describes what's happening, irrespective of our measurements</p></li><li><p>Can be extremely well tested or highly uncertain</p></li></ul><h2>Statistical Model</h2><ul><li><p>Describes process for generating data</p></li><li><p>Inevitably includes assumptions</p></li><li><p>Reecognizes that uncertainy is inevitable</p></li></ul><h3>Think of example sources of uncertainty</h3><ul><li><p>pause</p></li></ul></div>


<div class="markdown"><h2>Example Scientific Models</h2><ul><li><p>Newton's equation of motion &amp; gravitation</p></li><li><p>Keplerian motion of planets</p></li><li><p>Salpeter initial mass function for stars</p></li><li><p>ΛCMD model for growth of large scale structure</p></li></ul><h2>Example Statistical Models</h2><ul><li><p>Gaussian or Normal distribution for measurement uncertainties</p></li><li><p>Poisson distribution for number of photons hitting detector given expected photon rate</p></li><li><p>Binomial distribution for number of "successes" given number of trials and probability of success</p></li></ul></div>


<div class="nice-blockquote nice-blockquote__bordered nice-blockquote--quoted"><p class="nice-blockquote__text"></p><div class="markdown"><p>All models are wrong, but some are useful.</p></div><p></p><div class="nice-blockquote__text nice-blockquote__text--author"><div class="markdown"><p>– <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/All_models_are_wrong">George Box</a></p></div></div></div>

<div class="markdown"><h3>What is a (good) model useful for?</h3><ul><li><p>Making predictions</p></li><li><p>Incorporating new data to refine one's knowledge</p></li><li><p>Planning future science</p></li></ul></div>


<div class="markdown"><h4>Why are all models wrong?</h4><ul><li><p>pause</p></li></ul></div>


<div class="markdown"><h1>Probability</h1><ul><li><p>Multiple definitions and use cases</p></li><li><p>Surprisingly deep philosophical question</p></li><li><p>We'll adopt a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_probability">Bayesian interpretation of probability</a></p></li><li><p>We'll start with the Objective Bayesian interpretation of probability</p></li><li><p>Later we'll discuss the Subjective Bayesian interpretation</p></li></ul><p>Objective Bayesian</p><ul><li><p>Formalization of quantiative logic</p></li><li><p>Results of statistical inference depend only on the model and the data</p></li></ul></div>


<div class="markdown"><h2>Probability Function</h2><ul><li><p>Assigns a weight to each possible event/outcome of an experiment or observation.</p></li></ul></div>


<div class="markdown"><h3>Probability Mass Function</h3><ul><li><p>For discrete events/outcomes</p></li><li><p>Examples:  (pause to ask class)</p></li></ul><h2>Examples of Probability Mass Functions</h2><ul><li><p>Flip coin:  heads (H) or tails (T).  P(H) = P(T) = ½ </p></li><li><p>Roll an n-sided die:   P(V) = <span class="tex">\(\frac{1}{n}\)</span></p></li><li><p>Inspect locations a globe asking land or water:  </p></li></ul><p class="tex">$$p(\mathrm{Water}) = w$$</p><p class="tex">$$p(\mathrm{Land}) = 1-w$$</p></div>


<div class="markdown"><h2>Axioms of Probability</h2><ul><li><p>Non-negativity: <span class="tex">\(p(E)\ge0\)</span></p></li><li><p>Sum to unity:  <span class="tex">\(\sum_i p(E_i) = 1\)</span> for complete list of possible events</p></li><li><p>Sum of probabilities of mutually exclusive events: <span class="tex">\(p(\bigcup_i E_i) = \sum_i p(E_i)\)</span></p></li></ul></div>


<div class="markdown"><h2>Probability Density Function (PDF)</h2><ul><li><p>Allows for continuous events/outcomes</p></li><li><p>Examples: (ask class)</p></li></ul></div>


<div class="markdown"><h2>Examples of Probability Density Functions</h2><ul><li><p>Fraction of a planet covered with water: <span class="tex">\(p(w)\)</span></p></li><li><p>Mass of a star:  <span class="tex">\(p(M_\star)\)</span></p></li><li><p>Luminosity of a star:  <span class="tex">\(p(L_\star)\)</span></p></li><li><p>Value of future measurement of flux from a star:  <span class="tex">\(p(f_{\star,obs})\)</span></p></li></ul></div>


<div class="markdown"><h2>Probability function is about the state of knowledge.</h2><h4>It is not an intrinsic property of the system.</h4></div>


<div class="markdown"><h2>Likelihood function (<span class="tex">\(\mathcal{L(\theta)}\)</span>)</h2><ul><li><p>Probability distribution for the outcome of an experiment/observation that was made in the past, ignoring any current knowledge about the actual outcome.</p></li><li><p>A likelihood is a probability density function.  </p></li><li><p>Not all PDFs are likelihoods.</p></li><li><p>Likelihood function assumes a statistical model (commonly written <span class="tex">\(\mathcal{M}\)</span>).</p></li><li><p>Models often have parameters (commonly written as <span class="tex">\(\theta\)</span>)</p></li><li><p>Likelihood function often written: <span class="tex">\(\mathcal{L}(\theta)\)</span> or <span class="tex">\(\mathcal{L_M}(\theta)\)</span></p></li></ul><h4>Scientists often perform inference based on <span class="tex">\(\mathcal{L(\theta)}\)</span></h4><ul><li><p>E.g., Maximum Likelihood Estimate </p></li></ul><p class="tex">$$\hat{\theta}_{\mathrm{MLE}} = \mathrm{argmax}_\theta \, \mathcal{L(\theta)}$$</p><ul><li><p>Confidence Interval</p></li></ul><p class="tex">$$[\theta_l,\theta_u] = \cup \theta \; \mathrm{s.t.} \; \mathcal{L(\theta)} \le \mathcal{L}(\hat{\theta}_{\mathrm{MLE}}) + \Delta\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{thresh}}$$</p></div>


<div class="markdown"><div class="admonition is-tip"><header class="admonition-header">Tip</header><div class="admonition-body"><ul><li><p>The MLE is useful tool for your toolbox.  </p></li><li><p>For some models there are very efficienct methods for computing <span class="tex">\(\hat{\theta}\)</span>.</p></li><li><p>However, it is just a point estimate.</p></li><li><p>Be careful when many parameters, few observations, large uncertainties.</p></li><li><p>We'll use MLE as a short cut or starting point for more rigorous analysis.</p></li></ul></div></div></div>


<div class="markdown"><div class="admonition is-tip"><header class="admonition-header">Tip</header><div class="admonition-body"><p>In an ideal world, we'd use a Bayesian approach to uncertainty quantification.  But confidence intervals are used commonly enough that we at least need to understand what they are (and what they aren't).  </p></div></div></div>


<div class="markdown"><h1>Conditional Probability</h1><ul><li><p>Consider two events:                              <span class="tex">\(A\)</span> &amp; <span class="tex">\(B\)</span></p></li><li><p>Let each event have its own probability function: <span class="tex">\(p(A)\)</span> &amp; <span class="tex">\(p(B)\)</span></p></li><li><p><strong><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joint_probability_distribution">Joint probabilty</a></strong> of both events:              <span class="tex">\(p(A,B)\)</span></p></li><li><p><strong><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conditional_probability">Conditional probability</a></strong> of <span class="tex">\(A\)</span> given <span class="tex">\(B\)</span>:     <span class="tex">\(p(A|B)\)</span></p></li><li><p>Axiom of Conditional Probability: <span class="tex">\(p(A,B) = p(A) \, p(B|A)\)</span></p></li><li><p>Alternatively could write Conditional probability of <span class="tex">\(B\)</span> given <span class="tex">\(A\)</span>:         <span class="tex">\(p(B|A) = p(B) \, p(A|B)\)</span></p></li></ul></div>


<div class="markdown"><img controls="" src="data:image/png;base64," type="image/png" width="400"/><p>– Image Credit: <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joint_probability_distribution#/media/File:Multivariate_normal_sample.svg">Wikipedia</a><a href="https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0">CC BY-SA 3.0</a></p></div>


<div class="markdown"><h2>Bayes Theorem</h2><p>Start with Law of Conditional Probability:</p><p class="tex">$$p(A,B) = p(A) p(B|A) = p(B) p(A|B)$$</p><p>OR we might explicitly writeout the asumption of using model <span class="tex">\(M\)</span>:</p><p class="tex">$$p(A,B|M) = p(A|M) p(B|A,M) = p(B|M) p(A|B,M)$$</p><p>Can compute the marginal probabilities using law of total (conditional) probability:</p><ul><li><p>Discrete case:</p></li></ul><p class="tex">$$p(A) = \sum_{i} p(B_i) p(A|B_i)$$</p><p class="tex">$$p(B) = \sum_{i} p(A_i) p(B|A_i)$$</p><ul><li><p>Continuous case:</p></li></ul><p class="tex">$$p(A ) = \int dB \, p(B) p(A|B)$$</p><p class="tex">$$p(B ) = \int dA \, p(A) p(B|A)$$</p><p>To derive Baye's Theorem, substitute: </p><ul><li><p>A → <span class="tex">\(\theta\)</span>: model parameters</p></li><li><p>B → <span class="tex">\(D\)</span>: observed data </p></li><li><p><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prior_probability"><strong>Prior PDF</strong></a> for model parameters <span class="tex">\(p(\theta|M)\)</span> for <span class="tex">\(p(A)\)</span></p></li><li><p>Likelihood for observed data given model <span class="tex">\(\mathcal{L} = p(D|\theta, M)\)</span> for <span class="tex">\(p(B)\)</span></p></li></ul><p>into <span class="tex">\(p(D, \theta, M )\)</span>, the joint probability for both model parameters and observed data given the model <span class="tex">\(M\)</span>.</p><p class="tex">$$p(\theta, D, M) = p(\theta | M) p(D | \theta, M ) =  p(D | M ) p( \theta| M, D)$$</p><p>Solve for <span class="tex">\(p( \theta| M, D)\)</span>:</p><p class="tex">$$p( \theta| M, D) = \frac{p(\theta | M) p(D | \theta, M )}{p(D | M )}$$</p><h4>Interpretation of Bayes Theorem:</h4><p class="tex">$$\mathrm{(Posterior)} = \mathrm{(Prior)} \times \mathrm{(Likelihood)} / \mathrm{(Evidence)}$$</p></div>


<div class="markdown"><h4>Evidence term is often hard to calculate</h4><ul><li><p>Evidence is sometimes refered to as the "fully marginalized likelihood"</p></li></ul><h5>Discrete case:</h5><p class="tex">$$p(D | M ) = \sum_{i} p(\theta_i|M) p(D|\theta_i,M)$$</p><h5>Continuous case:</h5><p class="tex">$$p(D | M ) = \int d\theta \, p(\theta|M) p(D|\theta,M)$$</p></div>


<div class="markdown"><h2>Bayesian Inference</h2><ul><li><p>Bayesian inference about model parameters is based on the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Posterior_probability"><strong>posterior probability distribution</strong></a>. </p></li><li><p>Ideally, one uses the full posterior distribution.</p></li><li><p>Often, is can be helpful to summarize the posterior:  </p><ul><li><p>Approximate posterior distribution with a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normal_distribution"><strong>Normal Distribution</strong></a></p></li><li><p>Maximunm <em>a posteriori</em> Estimator (MAP): <span class="tex">\(\hat{\theta}_{\mathrm{MAP}} = \mathrm{argmax}_\theta \, p(\theta ) \, \mathcal{L(\theta )}\)</span></p></li><li><p>Fischer Information Matrix: Curvature of <span class="tex">\(p(\theta|D,M)\)</span> evaluated at MAP</p></li></ul></li></ul><p class="tex">$$I_{i,j} = \left. \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta_i} \frac{\partial}{\partial \theta_j} \log p(\theta|D,M) \right|_{\hat{\theta}_{MAP}}$$</p><ul><li><p>For many cases if you have a large, high-quality datasets and a model with few parameters, then the posterior distribution may be well approximated by a Gaussian Distribution, and  <span class="tex">\(\hat{\theta}_{\mathrm{MAP}} \approx \hat{\theta}_{\mathrm{MLE}}\)</span>.</p></li><li><p>However, there are also plenty of times when:</p><ul><li><p>MAP &amp; MLE differ</p></li><li><p>MAP &amp; MLE throws away infortant information about uncertainties.</p></li><li><p>Posterior might not be well approximated by a Gaussian (e.g., skewed, not unimodal).</p></li></ul></li><li><p>We want to build a toolbox that can work in both regimes.</p></li></ul></div>


<div class="markdown"><h1>Simplified Bayesian Model Building</h1><h2>Steps</h2><ol><li><p>Develop a statistical model describing how your data are generated.  This dictates the likelihood function and model parameters.</p></li><li><p>Choose prior distributions</p></li><li><p>Perform computations to estimate (or sample from) the posterior distribution.</p></li><li><p>Make decisions based on posterior distribution.</p></li></ol></div>


<div class="markdown"><h2>See Example Applications in Labs</h2></div>


<aside class="plutoui-aside-wrapper" style="top: 0px"><div><div class="markdown"><div class="admonition is-question"><header class="admonition-header">Question:</header><div class="admonition-body"><h2>After working through the labs, compare the Bayesian and frequentist approaches.   What are pros/cons?</h2></div></div></div></div></aside>

What contributed to that choice?</p></div></div></div></div></aside>

<div class="markdown"><h2>Axioms of Conditional Probability</h2><p class="tex">$$p(A|B)\ge0, \; \; \mathrm{if} \, p(B)&gt;0$$</p><p>.</p><p class="tex">$$\sum_i p(A_i|B) = p(B)$$</p><p class="tex">$$p(\bigcup_i A_i | B) = \sum_i p(A_i | B)$$</p></div>
